thread.title: CSU football notes: Quarterback controversy heats up
thread.title_full: CSU football notes: Quarterback controversy heats up

title: CSU football notes: Quarterback controversy heats up
text:
CSU football notes: Quarterback controversy heats up Colorado State'sColeman Key talks about quarterback controversy after loss to Boise State. Kelly Lyell/The Coloradoan Kelly Lyell , kellylyell@coloradoan.com 11:01 p.m. MDT October 10, 2015 Redshirt freshman Coleman Key took over early at quarterback for CSU’s football team in Saturday night’s loss to Boise State, only to be replaced late in the game by starter Nick Stevens. Coach Mike Bobo said afterward that he and his staff will have to decide Sunday which quarterback will be the starter moving forward. (Photo: Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan) 1 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
If there wasn’t a quarterback controversy before, there certainly is now for the CSU football team. 
Redshirt freshman Coleman Key and sophomore Nick Stevens each replaced the other during the course of Saturday night’s 41-10 loss to No. 25 Boise State at Hughes Stadium, and neither quarterback could say afterward who the starter would be come Monday. 
First-year coach Mike Bobo didn’t have an answer, either, saying the coaching staff would go over game video and meet Sunday to make that determination. 
“We’re going to meet and watch the film on Sunday and decide what direction, what we’re going to do, how we’re going to move the ball offensively,” Bobo said afterward. 
Stevens, the starter for all six games this season, was in for just five offensive plays before being replaced. The Rams managed just 5 yards on their first offensive series and had just two on the second, a sack for an 11-yard loss and a fumble by running back Dalyn Dawkins. 
Key came into the game on the third series and didn’t get much going immediately, either. But on the fourth series, he led the Rams on a 16-play, 75-yard scoring drive. His 13-yard touchdown pass to Joe Hansley cut the Boise State lead to 17-7. 
“I felt like I provided a spark early, but I’ve just got to be more consistent,” said Key, who completed just 5 of 19 passes for 56 yards, and threw two interceptions. 
Stevens had better passing numbers, completing 8 of 10 passes for 60 yards with no touchdowns or interceptions. But he was sacked three times, and was on the sidelines watching Key run the offense on both CSU scoring drives. 
“I think the biggest thing that me and Coleman have got to realize is we’re on the same team, and we’ve just got to root for each other while we’re in there,” Stevens said. “I wasn’t kind of complaining about it on the sideline. I was hoping for him to do well.” 
HIGGINS IS HUMAN: All-American CSU receiver Rashard Higgins had his string of three consecutive 100-yard receiving games snapped but still led the Rams with three catches for 42 yards. 
Higgins had 10 100-yard receiving games a year ago while earning consensus All-American honors and leading the nation in receiving yards (1,750) and touchdown receptions (17) — both school records — while making a school-record 96 catches. 
PASSING RECEIVER: CSU receiver Joe Hansley improved to 2 for 2 in his career as a passer, taking a lateral from Key and throwing a 34-yard pass to tight end Kivon Cartwright to set up a field goal late in the first half. 
Hansley’s only previous career passing attempt also was a 34-yarder to Cartwright on a fake field goal in a Sept. 28, 2013, win at UTEP. Hansley was lined up as the holder on the field goal try, a role he still holds. 
MORE TURNOVERS: CSU came into the game ranked among the bottom 10 teams in the nation in turnover margin at minus-9, and turned the ball over three times on two interceptions and a fumble against the Broncos. The Rams had just one takeaway, on an interception early in the second half by safety Nick Januska. 
Follow reporter Kelly Lyell at twitter.com/KellyLyell and facebook.com/KellyLyell.news. 1 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://noconow.co/1LoMhLP TOP VIDEOS
